revised_title: Ignition of Flammable Atmospheres by Radiation-Heated Fibrous Agglomerates: A Hazard Assessment
tldr: This study investigates the conditions under which laser radiation heats loose agglomerates of fine fibers or particles, leading to the ignition of a surrounding flammable gas mixture. The authors found that certain fuels, such as diethyl ether, hydrogen, and carbon disulfide, are more susceptible to this type of ignition than others. They propose a hazard assessment based on the concept of black body radiation interacting with a 'black' particle, which proves to be more hazardous than the worst case encountered in practice.
scientific_discipline: Engineering and Technology > Combustion and Fire Safety
